title: TCG Barbaros (F-244)
text:
TCG "Barbaros" (F-244) is the <a href="lead%20ship">lead ship</a> of of the <a href="Turkish%20Naval%20Forces">Turkish Navy</a>.
Development and design.
"Barbaros"-class frigates were designed in <a href="Germany">Germany</a> and are part of the <a href="MEKO">MEKO</a> group of modular warships, in this case the <a href="MEKO%20200">MEKO 200</a> design. Two ships were built in Germany and two in Turkey with German assistance. They are larger than the previous s and are also faster due to using <a href="CODOG">CODOG</a> machinery rather than pure diesels.
The first two vessels (F-244 and F-245) are defined as the "Barbaros" class (<a href="MEKO%20200">MEKO 200 TN Track II-A</a>) while the last two vessels (F-246 and F-247) are defined as the "Salih Reis" class (<a href="MEKO%20200">MEKO 200 TN Track II-B</a>) by the Turkish Navy.
"Salih Reis" subclass ships are built with 8-cell Mk. 41 VLS and longer than "Barbaros" class vessels to accommodate 16-cell Mk. 41 VLS upgrade in the future while "Barbaros"-class vessels built with <a href="RIM-7%20Sea%20Sparrow">Mk.29 Sea Sparrow</a> launchers that planned to be replaced by 8-cell <a href="Mark%2041%20Vertical%20Launching%20System">Mk. 41 VLS</a>.
Construction and career.
"Barbaros" was <a href="Launched%20%28ship%29">launched</a> on 29 September 1993 by <a href="Blohm%2BVoss">Blohm+Voss</a> in <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a> and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 23 May 1997.
On 9 March 2019, her crew saluted to the tomb of <a href="Hayreddin%20Barbarossa">Barbaros Hayreddin</a> while crossing <a href="Bosporus">Bosporus</a>.
On 26 August 2020, TCG "Barbaros" and <a href="TCG%20Burgazada">TCG Burgazada</a> sailed alongside <a href="USS%20Winston%20S.%20Churchill">USS Winston S. Churchill</a> in <a href="Mediterranean%20Sea">Eastern Mediterranean Sea</a>. Later that year on 3 October, she underwent alongside <a href="USS%20Roosevelt%20%28DDG-80%29">USS Roosevelt</a>.
